page.title: 15PRESERVATION OF BUILDINGS
page.content: In Theobald Street, Borehamwood, is a group of farm houses listed by the Department of the Environment for preservation as{historic buildings. There is local controversy since the buildings are in a poor state of repair and the Council plans to build homes on the site.{Conservationists are, however, fighting determinedly to ensure planning permission is refused. The buildings, known to have been mentioned in a will dated{1591,}are centred on a white, stucco-faced brick farmhouse built with a hipped roof of Welsh slate between 1800 and 1830. There is also a 16th. or 17th. century timber-framed aisled barn, a stable and bothy from the 18th. century, and a timber-framed granary, weather- boarded and again with a hipped slate roof, but unusual in that it is founded on cast-iron straddles.
